title: Tariff Turmoil Returns to Global Markets
partialText: Businesses and U.S. trade partners are again grappling with the uncertainty of President Trump’s trade war, even as he imposes new levies.

title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
partialText: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.

title: U.K., Australia and Others Worse Off Under Trump’s New Tariffs
partialText: Many important U.S. trading partners are facing higher duties after President Trump, reacting to a Supreme Court setback, set the rate on a new set of global tariffs at 15 percent.

title: What’s Happened Since the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
partialText: After the Trump administration’s punishing tariffs were invalidated, the president said he would impose new tariffs using a different authority. It’s been a whirlwind.

title: Fact-Check: Trump’s Latest Claims on Jobs, Inflation and Crime
partialText: Trends on jobs, inflation and crime that began before Donald Trump retook office continued, largely unabated, in his first year back.

title: Homeownership Is Out of Reach for Many Americans, Despite a Buyer’s Market
partialText: A growing split between low-to-middle-income families and wealthy households is changing who has access to homeownership now.

title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is Trending in Schools. Here’s Why.
partialText: Artificial intelligence companies are urging teachers to prepare students for an “A.I.-driven future.” What that means varies from school to school.

title: Need an Outfit? Pickle Clothing Rental App Helps Users Stay on Trend.
partialText: Pickle, a new peer-to-peer apparel-rental app, helps users stay on trend without having to go into debt or rely on climate-unfriendly fast fashion.

title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
partialText: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.

title: From Sundance Director to Head of Film Forum
partialText: Tabitha Jackson sees an opportunity to develop the next generation of cinephiles at the Greenwich Village art-house cinema.

title: Trump Calls on Netflix to Oust Susan Rice From Its Board
partialText: The president made the attack as Netflix and Paramount Skydance face a key deadline in a bidding war for Warner Bros. Discovery.

title: Trump Aides Project Confidence on Tariffs After Court Loss
partialText: Administration officials maintain that they can replicate the sky-high duties recently invalidated by the Supreme Court.

title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
partialText: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.

title: Should I Tell My Housekeeper, ‘I’m Here for You’?
partialText: Plus, what to do when your job interviewer spouts off on things better left unsaid.

title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
partialText: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?

title: A Roving Reporter on the Future of Transit in New York City
partialText: “A lot of interesting things happening in the city involve how people get around,” said Stefanos Chen, a Metro reporter and lifelong bus aficionado.

title: New York Nurses’ Strike Ends After 6 Weeks as Last Holdouts Approve Deal
partialText: Workers at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital voted for a contract with raises and layoff protections, meaning more than 4,000 nurses will return.

title: Traveling This Week? Here’s What to Know About the Blizzard.
partialText: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and a long list of delays and cancellations across much of the Northeast.

title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
partialText: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it

title: JPMorgan Admits to Debanking Trump After Jan. 6 Capitol Attacks
partialText: Nation’s largest bank, in response to a lawsuit filed by the president, confirmed his longstanding complaint about “debanking.”

title: Trump Says He Will Raise Global Tariff to 15 Percent
partialText: The move signaled that the president would press ahead with steep global import taxes despite the legal setback from the Supreme Court.

title: Six Questions on the Future of Trump’s Tariffs
partialText: The Supreme Court’s ruling on the president’s tariffs has jolted Washington and the business world. Here’s what to watch next.

title: Inside the Big Tech Lobbying Machine Aiming to Halt Social Media Bans
partialText: Tech giants, including Meta and Alphabet, are spending lavishly on splashy billboard ads, courting on-the-fence politicians and bulking up their ranks of lobbyists.

title: For India, Buying Russian Oil Just Got More Complicated
partialText: India’s prime minister acceded to many of President Trump’s demands under pressure of heavy tariffs. It would be awkward to reject them now.

title: Fred Segal Has a New Owner. This Time It’s Aritzia.
partialText: The storied Los Angeles retailer, once recognized as an arbiter of West Coast style, has been acquired by the mass-market brand Aritzia.

title: He Researched Dishonesty. He Got Friendly With Jeffrey Epstein.
partialText: Dan Ariely, a behavioral scientist at Duke, sought out the convicted sex offender for his research. Their yearslong correspondence suggests it wasn’t all business.

title: Trump Doubles Down on Closing Tax Loophole on Cheap Imports
partialText: The exemption was shut down last year by President Trump based, in part, on the same legal grounds as the tariffs that were invalidated by the Supreme Court.

title: ‘Murky Waters’ for Global Businesses After Trump’s Tariff Loss
partialText: Even after the Supreme Court invalidated many of the president’s levies, foreign leaders and executives assume that U.S. tariffs are here to stay, in one form or another.

title: With Tariff Changes, Consumers May Be Stuck in a Waiting Game
partialText: Some companies could decide to temper price increases, but the effect would take time to materialize.

title: Ask The Morning: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
partialText: The justices struck down a central piece of President Trump’s agenda. What does that mean?

title: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling to Spur Chaotic Refund Process
partialText: The Trump administration says it could take years and additional litigation for importers to get their money back.

title: Businesses Celebrate Tariff Relief, And Brace for New Uncertainty
partialText: The Supreme Court’s ruling against many of President Trump’s tariffs cheered executives who set to work seeking refunds on their duties.

title: After Tariff Decision, What Happens to Trump’s Deals With China, Canada and Europe?
partialText: The Supreme Court’s decision to invalidate many of President Trump’s tariffs raised questions about what would become of agreements struck with major U.S. trading partners.

title: Tariff Whiplash Clouds Outlook for Federal Budget
partialText: The tariffs thrown out by the Supreme Court had become an important revenue source. President Trump said he could replace that money with other levies.

title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
partialText: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.

title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
partialText: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.

title: Supreme Court Justices Strike Down Trump’s Tariffs
partialText: President Trump was the first to invoke the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to set tariffs on imported goods from more than 100 countries.

title: A Cancer Detection Test Fails in Major Study
partialText: A closely watched clinical trial in Britain that screened blood for early detection of cancer did not show a reduction in diagnoses at later stages of the disease.

title: U.S. Economy Grew Modestly at End of 2025
partialText: Gross domestic product expanded at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of the year, hit by the effects of the government shutdown.

title: Is Blue Owl Private Credit’s ‘Canary in the Coal Mine’?
partialText: Steep declines in the shares of private lenders, after a major fund changed how investors can withdraw money, have sparked worries about more trouble to come.

title: Mixed Signals Churn Stock Market Despite Recent Highs
partialText: Major indexes have mostly been treading water for months, as investors’ exuberance for artificial intelligence wears off.

title: Can an A.I. Productivity Boom Clear a Path for More Rate Cuts? Trump’s Fed Pick Thinks So.
partialText: As Federal Reserve chair, Kevin M. Warsh may face a tough task persuading his colleagues to lower borrowing costs because of potential productivity gains.

title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
partialText: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.

title: Trump and Indonesia Sign Trade Deal, Locking In 19% Tariffs
partialText: The countries made official an agreement reached last year, with Indonesia avoiding a higher tariff and committing to cooperate on export controls.

title: Blue Owl Capital Sets Off New Fears About the Private Credit Industry
partialText: The lender’s announcement that investors will no longer be able to ask for a set amount of money back from its funds prompted worries about the private credit industry.

title: Trump Administration Uses ‘Equal Time’ Rule to Reshape Late-Night TV
partialText: The F.C.C. is using the “equal time” provision to take aim at hosts like Stephen Colbert. The impact could reshape how talk shows handle politics.

title: Labor Secretary’s Husband Barred From Department Premises After Reports of Sexual Assaults
partialText: At least two female staff members said Dr. Shawn DeRemer had touched them inappropriately at the agency in Washington.

title: Some Reese’s Treats Drop the Milk Chocolate. Mr. Reese Disapproves.
partialText: With cocoa prices high, Hershey’s has changed some of its candy recipes. The grandson of the man who invented the original Peanut Butter Cup said he was “embarrassed.”

title: Bill Gates Cancels Speech in India Amid Epstein Controversy
partialText: The philanthropist made the announcement on Thursday, after having earlier confirmed his participation in a prominent artificial intelligence summit in India.

title: Doing Your Taxes? We Want to Hear From You.
partialText: The New York Times is looking to speak to Americans about how the most recent tax cuts are affecting their pocketbooks.
